*[Bug 18930] New: Inconsistent behaviour of merge() on empty DF*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18930>

            Bug ID: 18930
           Summary: Inconsistent behaviour of merge() on empty DF
           Product: R
           Version: old
          Hardware: Other
                OS: Other
            Status: UNCONFIRMED
          Severity: normal
          Priority: P5
         Component: Language
          Assignee: <mailto:R-core@R-project.org|R-core@R-project.org>
          Reporter: <mailto:dmolnar100@icloud.com|dmolnar100@icloud.com>

merge() is inconsistent with column naming if one of the merged data frames is
empty. Behaviour depends purely on whether there are 2 or more columns, not on
the types of columns or names of columns. 

This inconsistency makes it necessary to handle empty DF cases separately. 



Examples:

> a <- data.frame(x=numeric())
> b <- data.frame(y=1:2)
> merge(x=a, y=b, all.x=TRUE, all.y=TRUE)
     [,1] [,2]
attr(,"row.names")
integer(0)


> a <- data.frame(x=numeric(), y=numeric())
> b <- data.frame(z=1:2)
> merge(x=a, y=b, all.x=TRUE, all.y=TRUE)
[1] x          y          y[FALSE, ]
<0 rows> (or 0-length row.names)



However:

> a <- data.frame(x=4:5)
> b <- data.frame(y=1:2)
> merge(x=a, y=b, all.x=TRUE, all.y=TRUE)
  x y
1 4 1
2 5 1
3 4 2
4 5 2

> a <- data.frame(x=4:5, y=7:8)
> b <- data.frame(z=1:2)
> merge(x=a, y=b, all.x=TRUE, all.y=TRUE)
  x y z
1 4 7 1
2 5 8 1
3 4 7 2
4 5 8 2

<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=15772>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #3 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
By now C nrows() is part of the API (see R-exts). Still, the function is meant
to be used for matrices. As  you found, it doesn't work for data frames, at
least since they are implemented on top of (new) lists. I've removed the old
and no longer used (and no longer working) data frame code from the
implementation to avoid confusion.

Whenever there is R API for something, but not public C API, one can consider
going to R (via eval). R function NROW() handles data frames and the underlying
code is similar to what you've been proposing.

*[Bug 17208] strptime, "%OS" and "."*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17208>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |WONTFIX

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
Yes, the implementation parses the value for %OS using wstrtod(), which
supports numbers like "14.", so the dot will be part of the number. Also it
then supports numbers like "14.2e-2", which might also cause confusion in some
cases.

This is how it has been for many years, and it is not obviously wrong, even
though perhaps someone might prefer a more restrictive design. It is possible
that there is user code relying on the current behavior, e.g. one could use

strptime("17_35_14..mp3","%H_%M_%OS.mp3")

to make sure there is ".mp3" at the end, and that would break if we suddenly
excluded the first "." from the number.

So I think it is safer to keep the implementation as it is. In theory, we could
introduce another (again non-standard) way to enter fractional seconds, say %f
(like Python), but it doesn't seem worth the code duplication. If the C
standard is ever extended to support fractional seconds in strptime, then
perhaps we should support that, possibly leaving the "%OS" around for
back-compatibility.

*[Bug 17664] Provide a function getListElement like the one described in Writing R Extensions and/or clarify its terms of use.*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17664>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
         Resolution|---                         |WONTFIX
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I think this question would been better suited for R-devel mailing list,
hopefully one would get an answer there much faster.

Unlike mkNamed(), getListElement() is not used in base R (only in stats and
grid, which each have their copy). The C API of R is already so big that one
should think hard before adding even more functions, especially when they are
not even used in base R.

I see the function mostly as an example on how lists work, and it serves also
that purpose in the documentation. In some specific cases, when the lists are
short and not accessed much, and indeed if the names are always ASCII only, the
function may be good enough. But in other cases, having to always load the
strings and compare them will be slow, linear search will be slow. When one has
control over the list structure and the structure is fixed, I think it makes
sense using fixed indexes - one can have enums/constants for those in the C
code. So for me this is another reason for not adding the function to base R
itself.

I am not a lawyer and you would not get a legal advice here. But I hope one
shouldn't have to ever worry about copying a function from the manual into your
code (and if I did that, I would add a comment it was from Writing R Extensions
- not only credit but also for maintenance reasons).

*[Bug 18377] Replace paste(sep = "") with paste0() in some vignettes, demos, tests*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18377>

--- Comment #5 from Michael Chirico (<mailto:michaelchirico4@gmail.com|michaelchirico4@gmail.com>) ---
> on the other hand one needs to know one more function with not necessarily an intuitive name

It's not perfectly transparent but there are far worse names in default
packages. At a very rough level there's already ~2x more `paste0()` usage on
CRAN than `paste(sep="")`:

<https://github.com/search?q=org%3Acran+%2F%5B%5E%5Cw.%5Dpaste0%5C%28%2F&type=code>
<https://github.com/search?q=org%3Acran+%2F%5B%5E%5Cw.%5Dpaste%5C%28%2F+%2Fsep%5Cs*%3D%5Cs*%5B%27%22%5D%7B2%7D%2F&type=code>

One motivation for the switch was this in `?paste0`:

> paste0(..., collapse) is equivalent to paste(..., sep = "", collapse), slightly more efficiently.

However, I wasn't able to find evidence of that just now in simple examples --
possibly that note is obsolete (it was added alongside `paste0()` 14 years ago)
or could go for clarification.
